Improving the Sampling Strategy in KernelSHAP

Lars Henry Berge Olsen E-mail address to corresponding author: lholsen@math.uio.no. Department of Mathematics, University of Oslo Martin Jullum Norwegian Computing Center
(October 7, 2024)
Abstract

Shapley values are a popular model-agnostic explanation framework for explaining predictions made by complex machine learning models. The framework provides feature contribution scores that sum to the predicted response and represent each feature‚Äôs importance. The computation of exact Shapley values is computationally expensive due to estimating an exponential amount of non-trivial conditional expectations. The KernelSHAP framework enables us to approximate the Shapley values using a sampled subset of weighted conditional expectations. We propose three main novel contributions: a stabilizing technique to reduce the variance of the weights in the current state-of-the-art strategy, a novel weighing scheme that corrects the Shapley kernel weights based on sampled subsets, and a straightforward strategy that includes the important subsets and integrates them with the corrected Shapley kernel weights. We compare these new approximation strategies against existing ones by evaluating their Shapley value accuracy as a function of the number of subsets. The results demonstrate that our sampling strategies significantly enhance the accuracy of the approximated Shapley value explanations, making them more reliable in practical applications. This work provides valuable insights and practical recommendations for researchers and practitioners seeking to implement Shapley value-based explainability of their models.

Keywords: Explainable artificial intelligence, Shapley values, model-agnostic explanation, prediction explanation, feature dependence

1 Introduction

The field of Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) has developed various explanation frameworks to provide insights into the inner workings of complex models and to make their predictions more understandable to humans \parenciteadadi2018peeking, covert2021explaining, molnar2019. Developing and adopting XAI frameworks is crucial for bridging the gap between model complexity and transparency, trustworthiness, and explainability. When properly used, XAI can foster better decision-making, ensure compliance with regulatory standards, and facilitate model debugging by enabling practitioners/stakeholders to comprehend their model‚Äôs decision-making process \parenciteebers2020regulating, schwalbe2023comprehensive. As machine learning continues to evolve, the role of XAI will become increasingly important in ensuring that the benefits of advanced models are harnessed responsibly and effectively. One of the most used explanation frameworks is Shapley values \parenciteshapley1953value, molnar2023SHAP.

Shapley values stem from cooperative game theory but are in the context of XAI, often used as a post-hoc model-agnostic local explanation framework that explains the prediction f‚Å¢(ùíô)ùëìùíôf(\boldsymbol{x})italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) made by a complex model fùëìfitalic_f. Post-hoc means that the explanations are made after the model has been trained and its predictions made. That is, the explanations are not inherently built into the model but are derived from its behavior. Model-agnostic means that we can explain any model fùëìfitalic_f, and local means that we explain the prediction of a single observation ùíôùíô\boldsymbol{x}bold_italic_x called the explicand. The explanation is a vector of feature contributions œïbold-italic-œï\boldsymbol{\phi}bold_italic_œï that sums to the predicted response.

In this paper, we consider the setting of supervised learning and provide Shapley values to explain a predictive model f‚Å¢(ùíô)ùëìùíôf(\boldsymbol{x})italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) trained on ùí≥={ùíô[i],y[i]}i=1Ntrainùí≥superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùíôdelimited-[]ùëñsuperscriptùë¶delimited-[]ùëñùëñ1subscriptùëÅtrain\mathcal{X}=\{\boldsymbol{x}^{[i]},y^{[i]}\}_{i=1}^{N_{\text{train}}}caligraphic_X = { bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT train end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Here ùíô[i]superscriptùíôdelimited-[]ùëñ\boldsymbol{x}^{[i]}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an MùëÄMitalic_M-dimensional feature vector, y[i]superscriptùë¶delimited-[]ùëñy^{[i]}italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a univariate response, and NtrainsubscriptùëÅtrainN_{\text{train}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT train end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the number of training observations. However, Shapley values can be extended to provide global explanations, i.e., explaining global model effects across all observations \parenciteowen2014sobol, covert2020understanding, frye_shapley-based_2020, and to other domains: images \parencitefastshap, text \parencitechen2018shapley, graphs \parencitewang2021shapley, duval2021graphsvx, and series of models \parencitechen2022explaining. \textcitemolnar2019 provides a detailed overview and introduction to other explanation frameworks such as accumulated local effects, local interpretable model-agnostic explanations, and counterfactual explanations.

We focus on conditional Shapley values, which incorporates feature dependencies into the explanations \parenciteaas2019explaining. This is in contrast to marginal Shapley values where one omits the dependencies. The two versions coincide when there are no dependencies between features, and the methods proposed in this paper also apply to marginal Shapley values. The conditional Shapley values are consistent with standard probability axioms \parencite[Proposition 7]covert2021explaining, but this consistency comes at the cost of increased computational complexity due to the necessity of modeling dependencies between arbitrary feature combinations. Throughout this article, we refer to conditional Shapley values when discussing Shapley values unless otherwise specified.

In general, computing Shapley values is an NP-hard problem \parencitedeng1994complexity, faigle1992shapley, and the direct computations are exponential in the number of features MùëÄMitalic_M. A wide range of approximation strategies have been proposed, which are either based on model assumptions (making the explanations model-specific) or model-agnostic methods that use stochastic, sampling-based estimators that are correct in expectation. The model-agnostic methods are connected to different but equivalent formulations of Shapley values. Shapley values can be viewed as a semivalue \parencitecastro2009polynomial, least squares value \parencitecharnes1988extremal, random order value \parencitemonderer2002variations, or a multilinear extension \parenciteOwenMulti. See \textcitechen2023algorithms for a more in-depth introduction to these Shapley value formulations.

We compute Shapley values by solving a weighted least squares problem, thus focusing on approximation strategies tied to the least squares value formulation. More specifically, we propose enhancements to the KernelSHAP approximation framework \parencitelundberg2017unified and the current state-of-the-art strategy \parencitecovert2021explaining to lower the computational complexity and improve the tractability. KernelSHAP approximates Shapely values using a (weighted) subset of the exponential number of feature combinations. We introduce novel strategies to select and weigh the elements of this subset using stabilizing techniques and corrected Shapley kernel values based on the sampled subset.

Section 2 introduces the Shapley value explanation framework and how to compute them exactly and approximate them using the KernelSHAP framework. Section 3 discusses the current state-of-the-art approximation strategies and our novel extensions and strategies. Section 4 presents numerical simulation studies comparing the accuracy of the different approximation strategies, while Section 5 conducts experiments on real-world data. Finally, Section 6 provides conclusions and outlines further work. The Appendix includes implementation details, other strategies, and additional information.

The conditional expectation summarizes the whole probability distribution, it is the most common estimator in prediction applications, and it is also the minimizer of the commonly used squared error loss function \parenciteaas2019explaining. Note that the last equality of (2) only holds for continuous features. If there are any discrete or categorical features, the integral should be replaced by sums for these features. Computing (2) is not straightforward for a general data distribution and model. Assuming independent features, or having fùëìfitalic_f be linear, simplifies the computations \parencitelundberg2017unified, aas2019explaining, but these assumptions do not generally hold. To obtain accurate conditional Shapley values, we need to generate Monte Carlo samples that follow the true conditional distribution of the data.

2.1 Approximation Strategies

In this section, we highlight procedures that use approximations or model assumptions to reduce the computational complexity of the Shapley value explanation framework and make the computations tractable in higher dimensions. The approximative speed-up strategies can be divided into model-specific and model-agnostic strategies \parencitechen2023algorithms.

The model-specific strategies put assumptions on the predictive model fùëìfitalic_f to improve the computational cost, but some of the strategies are restricted to marginal Shapley values. For conditional Shapley values, \textciteaas2019explaining,chen2020true derive explicit expressions for linear models to speed up the computations, and \textcitelundberg2020local proposes the path-dependent TreeSHAP algorithm for tree-based models. \textciteyang2021fast improves the speed of the TreeSHAP algorithm by pre-computing expensive steps at the cost of a slightly higher memory consumption. While \textcitebifet2022linear reduce the time complexity from polynomial to linear time with their Linear TreeSHAP algorithm and \textcitemuschalik2024beyond extend it to any-order Shapley interaction index scores \parencitegrabisch1999axiomatic. There are also speed-up strategies for deep neural network models, but they are limited to marginal Shapley values \parenciteancona2019explaining, wang2020shapley.

The model-agnostic strategies put no assumptions on the predictive model fùëìfitalic_f and often use stochastic sampling-based estimators \parenciteaas2019explaining, lundberg2017unified, okhrati2021multilinear, mitchell2022sampling. That is, to speed up the computations, they approximate the Shapley value explanations by a sampled subset of the coalitions instead of considering the exponential amount of them. Thus, the strategies are stochastic; however, their expectations are unbiased. One of the most common model-agnostic strategies is the KernelSHAP strategy introduced in \textcitelundberg2017unified and improved by \textcitecovert2021improving. In the KernelSHAP strategy, we sample, e.g., NùíÆ<2MsubscriptùëÅùíÆsuperscript2ùëÄN_{\mathcal{S}}<2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coalitions and use only these coalitions to approximate the Shapley value explanations using the least squares value formulation. This strategy enables us to approximate the explanations in tractable time even for large values of MùëÄMitalic_M; however, an NùíÆ‚â™2Mmuch-less-thansubscriptùëÅùíÆsuperscript2ùëÄN_{\mathcal{S}}\ll 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â™ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will (likely) produce poor approximations.

There exist other approximation strategies linked to alternative Shapley formulations, such as the permutation sampling-based frameworks based on the random order value formulation \parencitestrumbelj2010efficient, strumbelj2014explaining, chen2022algorithms. We prefer the KernelSHAP framework over permutation sampling-based frameworks due to its superior efficiency. In the context of conditional Shapley values, the primary computational burden is related to the number of v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values that need to be calculated. KernelSHAP leverages all computed v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values to determine the Shapley values for all features. In contrast, permutation sampling only uses a portion of the evaluated v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values to estimate each feature‚Äôs Shapley value, resulting in less efficient utilization of these values. Examples of approximation strategies for the permutation sampling-based framework include orthogonal spherical codes \parencitemitchell2022sampling, stratified sampling \parencitecastro2017improving, maleki2015addressing, paired sampling \parencitecovert2021improving, mitchell2022sampling, and many others \parencitemitchell2022sampling, van2018new, illes2019estimation. However, these strategies typically cannot be directly integrated into the KernelSHAP approximation framework and are thus considered outside the scope of this article.

We refer to \textcitechen2023algorithms for more details about the model-agnostic and model-specific strategies. \textcitefastshap propose to sidestep the Shapley value formula by training a black-box neural network to directly output the Shapley value explanations, while \textcitejullum2021groupshapley explain groups of similar/correlated features instead of individual features to reduce the computations.

The ùëπùëπ\boldsymbol{R}bold_italic_R matrix is independent of the explicands. When explaining NexplainsubscriptùëÅexplainN_{\text{explain}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT predictions, we can replace ùíóùíó\boldsymbol{v}bold_italic_v with a 2M√óNexplainsuperscript2ùëÄsubscriptùëÅexplain2^{M}\times N_{\text{explain}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT √ó italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT matrix ùëΩùëΩ\boldsymbol{V}bold_italic_V, where column iùëñiitalic_i contains the contribution functions for the iùëñiitalic_ith explicand.

Exact computations are infeasible in higher dimensions as the number of coalitions 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT grows exponentially with the number of features MùëÄMitalic_M. A common solution is to approximate the Shapley values by solving (4) using a sampled subset of coalitions ùíü‚äÜùí´‚Å¢(‚Ñ≥)ùíüùí´‚Ñ≥{\mathcal{D}}\subseteq{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{M}})caligraphic_D ‚äÜ caligraphic_P ( caligraphic_M ) (with replacement) instead of all coalitions ùíÆ‚ààùí´‚Å¢(‚Ñ≥)ùíÆùí´‚Ñ≥{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{M}})caligraphic_S ‚àà caligraphic_P ( caligraphic_M ). This framework is called KernelSHAP \parencitelundberg2017unified, and the coalitions are sampled from a distribution following the Shapley kernel weights in (6). Thus, the sampled subsets are weighted equally in the new weighted least squares problem, while the empty and grand coalitions are always included and exempt from the sampling. The corresponding Shapley value approximation is

œïùíü=(ùíÅùíüT‚Å¢ùëæùíü‚Å¢ùíÅùíü)‚àí1‚Å¢ùíÅùíüT‚Å¢ùëæùíü‚Å¢ùíóùíü,subscriptbold-italic-œïùíüsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùíÅùíüùëásubscriptùëæùíüsubscriptùíÅùíü1superscriptsubscriptùíÅùíüùëásubscriptùëæùíüsubscriptùíóùíü\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\phi}_{{\mathcal{D}}}=(\boldsymbol{Z}_{{\mathcal{D}}}% ^{T}\boldsymbol{W}_{{\mathcal{D}}}\boldsymbol{Z}_{{\mathcal{D}}})^{-1}% \boldsymbol{Z}_{{\mathcal{D}}}^{T}\boldsymbol{W}_{{\mathcal{D}}}\boldsymbol{v}% _{{\mathcal{D}}},bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (7)

where only the NùíÆ=|ùíü|subscriptùëÅùíÆùíüN_{\mathcal{S}}=|{\mathcal{D}}|italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | caligraphic_D | unique coalitions in ùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D are used. If a coalition ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S is sampled KùêæKitalic_K times, then the corresponding weight in ùëæùíü=diag‚Å°(C,ùíòùíü,C)subscriptùëæùíüdiagùê∂subscriptùíòùíüùê∂\boldsymbol{W}_{\mathcal{D}}=\operatorname{diag}(C,\boldsymbol{w}_{\mathcal{D}% },C)bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_diag ( italic_C , bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C ), denoted by wùíÆsubscriptùë§ùíÆw_{\mathcal{S}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is proportional to KùêæKitalic_K, as we normalize the weights for numerical stability. The KernelSHAP framework is also useful in lower dimensions if v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) is expensive to compute. \textcitewilliamson2020efficient shows that the KernelSHAP approximation framework is consistent and asymptotically unbiased, while \textcitecovert2021improving shows that it is empirically unbiased for even a modest number of coalitions.

3 Sampling Strategies

In this section, we describe established and novel strategies for selecting the NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions in ùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D and how to weigh them in (7) when approximating Shapley value explanations. We provide an overview of the strategies and their characteristic properties in Table 1. The empty and grand coalitions are always included in the approximations; thus, they are excluded from the sampling procedure. Consequently, NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an integer between (exclusive) 2222 and 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as the full set of coalitions yields exact Shapley values. In Appendix E, we discuss alternative strategies that were investigated but performed worse. In Appendix G, we demonstrate that our novel techniques can significantly enhance the strategy used in the SHAP Python library \parenciteshap_python.

In Figures 1 and 2, we illustrate the weights used in (7) by the strategies introduced below when normalized over the NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions in ùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D. Figure 1 focuses on an M=10ùëÄ10M=10italic_M = 10-dimensional setting with NùíÆ‚àà{100,250,750,1000}subscriptùëÅùíÆ1002507501000N_{\mathcal{S}}\in\{100,250,750,1000\}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà { 100 , 250 , 750 , 1000 }. We index the coalitions by first ordering them based on coalition size, i.e., {1}1\{1\}{ 1 } precedes {1,2}12\{1,2\}{ 1 , 2 }, and then by their elements for equal-sized coalitions, i.e., {1,2}12\{1,2\}{ 1 , 2 } precedes {1,3}13\{1,3\}{ 1 , 3 }. This indexing ensures that coalitions with indices iùëñiitalic_i and 2M+1‚àíisuperscript2ùëÄ1ùëñ2^{M}+1-i2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 - italic_i are complementary, for i=1,2,‚Ä¶,2Mùëñ12‚Ä¶superscript2ùëÄi=1,2,\dots,2^{M}italic_i = 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶ , 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as seen by the paired strategy‚Äôs weights being symmetric around the dashed vertical lines in Figure 1. The weights of the empty (i=1ùëñ1i=1italic_i = 1) and grand (i=2M=1024ùëñsuperscript2ùëÄ1024i=2^{M}=1024italic_i = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1024) coalitions are omitted as they are strategy-independent and infinite.

3.2 Paired

The paired strategy improves the unique strategy by using a variance reduction technique for Monte Carlo methods called paired sampling333Also called antithetic and halved sampling in the literature \parencitechen2023algorithms. \parencite[Ch. 9]kroese2013handbook. \textcitecovert2021improving demonstrates that paired sampling reduces the variance of the Shapley values approximations compared to the unique strategy. The paired sampling strategy pairs each sampled coalition ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S, determined by the unique strategy, with its complement/inverse ùíÆ =‚Ñ≥\ùíÆ ùíÆ\‚Ñ≥ùíÆ{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}={\mathcal{M}}\backslash{% \mathcal{S}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG = caligraphic_M \ caligraphic_S. This will be useful in the remainder of the paper when we talk about coalition size as then |ùíÆ|‚â§‚åäM/2‚åãùíÆùëÄ2|{\mathcal{S}}|\leq\lfloor M/2\rfloor| caligraphic_S | ‚â§ ‚åä italic_M / 2 ‚åã, where ‚åä‚ãÖ‚åã‚ãÖ\lfloor\cdot\rfloor‚åä ‚ãÖ ‚åã denotes the floor function. Conceptually, we only sample coalitions ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S with coalition indices less than or equal to 2M‚àí1superscript2ùëÄ12^{M-1}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and then add their paired counterparts ùíÆ  ùíÆ{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG with coalition indices larger than 2M‚àí1superscript2ùëÄ12^{M-1}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The probability of sampling ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S is then pùíÆ+pùíÆ =2‚Å¢pùíÆsubscriptùëùùíÆsubscriptùëù ùíÆ2subscriptùëùùíÆp_{\mathcal{S}}+p_{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}=2p_{% \mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where pùíÆsubscriptùëùùíÆp_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given in (8). However, the doubling is redundant when normalizing the probabilities, as all coalitions have doubled their probability. Note that NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will always be an even number for the paired strategy. 3.3 Paired Average

We name the strategy for paired average as we achieve this by averaging the sampling frequencies of the sampled coalitions within each coalition size. This means that the stabilized weights wùíÆsubscriptùë§ùíÆw_{\mathcal{S}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are given by

The paired and paired average strategies are identical for coalition sizes where no coalition has been sampled more than once. The paired average sampling strategy is more stable and its weights tend faster to pùíÆsubscriptùëùùíÆp_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in (8) when NùíÆ‚Üí2M‚ÜísubscriptùëÅùíÆsuperscript2ùëÄN_{\mathcal{S}}\rightarrow 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT than the unique and paired strategies; see Figure 1. To the best of our knowledge, the paired average strategy is a novel extension to the paired strategy.

A natural extension to reduce the variance of the weights wùíÆsubscriptùë§ùíÆw_{\mathcal{S}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT further is to repeat the sampling step BùêµBitalic_B times and use the empirical means of (11) as the new and more stable weights. We include this strategy in Appendix E and call it paired empirical. However, the performance is more or less identical to the paired c-kernel strategy, which we introduce below in Section 3.5.

3.4 Paired Kernel

As the weights of the paired average strategy tend to the normalized Shapley kernel weights pùíÆsubscriptùëùùíÆp_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given in (8) and the exact Shapley value computations use these weights, a natural consideration is to also use these directly as weights when we approximate the Shapley values. In the paired kernel strategy, we sample the coalitions as in the paired strategy, but we let the weights be

wùíÆ‚àùpùíÆ.proportional-tosubscriptùë§ùíÆsubscriptùëùùíÆ\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{S}}\propto p_{\mathcal{S}}.italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àù italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (12)

See Table 2 for the values of pùíÆsubscriptùëùùíÆp_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some dimensionalities. Coalitions of equal size have the same weight in the paired kernel strategy. In Appendix B, we demonstrate and explore the relation between the paired average and paired kernel strategies.

3.5 Paired C-Kernel

The paired c-kernel strategy corrects the weights in the paired kernel strategy by conditioning on the coalitions being sampled at least once. For ease of understanding, we first explain the correction technique for the unique setting before we extend it to the paired setting, which is the one we use.

In contrast, simulating 1000100010001000 LùêøLitalic_L values and computing their mean takes a few minutes using a single thread, with only minuscule differences in the results, see Figure 16 in Appendix C. Some of the long computation time can be attributed to the gmp package \parencitegmp, which is necessary to handle arbitrary precision arithmetic. The integer class in R cannot store large enough integers and the numeric class lacks sufficient precision, which leads to floating point errors that become significant when accumulated.. 3.7 Paired Imp C-Kernel

The paired imp c-kernel strategy extends the paired c-kernel strategy by including the most important paired coalitions, i.e., those with the largest Shapley kernel weights, first. This involves initially including coalitions ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S with one feature together with their complements ùíÆ  ùíÆ{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG with M‚àí1ùëÄ1M-1italic_M - 1 features, followed by coalitions with two features together with their complements with M‚àí2ùëÄ2M-2italic_M - 2 features, and so on. We sample which coalitions to include in a paired manner for the coalition size where not all coalitions are included. That is, if NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is even, both ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S and its complement ùíÆ  ùíÆ{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG are included, while only ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S is included when NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is odd.

For clarity, consider an example with M=10ùëÄ10M=10italic_M = 10 and NùíÆ=25subscriptùëÅùíÆ25N_{\mathcal{S}}=25italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 25. The strategy first includes all size zero and one coalitions along with their paired complements, of which there are two and twenty coalitions, respectively. For the remaining three coalitions, we sample two coalitions uniformly (without replacement) from size-two coalitions, e.g., {1,2}12\{1,2\}{ 1 , 2 } and {5,9}59\{5,9\}{ 5 , 9 }. We then include the paired complement of the first sampled coalition, {3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10}345678910\{3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10\}{ 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 , 8 , 9 , 10 }, to reach the target of twenty-five coalitions. In Section E.3, we outline and discuss potential methods to include the coalitions based on pilot estimates of their importance instead of random sampling to improve the strategy.

The paired imp c-kernel strategy applies the Shapley kernel weight correction in (14) to obtain the weights wùíÆsubscriptùë§ùíÆw_{\mathcal{S}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT used in (7) when approximating Shapley values. However, the semi-deterministic inclusion method means that L=NùíÆùêøsubscriptùëÅùíÆL=N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_L = italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the corresponding weights are therefore given by

wùíÆ‚àù2‚Å¢pùíÆ1‚àí(1‚àí2‚Å¢pùíÆ)NùíÆ/2.proportional-tosubscriptùë§ùíÆ2subscriptùëùùíÆ1superscript12subscriptùëùùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆ2\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{S}}\propto\frac{2p_{\mathcal{S}}}{1-(1-2p_{\mathcal{% S}})^{N_{\mathcal{S}}/2}}.italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àù divide start_ARG 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - ( 1 - 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (20)

A consequence of the semi-deterministic inclusion is that the correction in (14) becomes invalid since it relies on the assumption that the sampling probability of coalition ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S is pùíÆsubscriptùëùùíÆp_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, (20) will not converge to the exact Shapley values when NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approaches 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is illustrated by the dashed curves in Figure 2 not converging to the dots, which represent the Shapley kernel weights.

3.8 Paired Imp CEL-Kernel

The paired imp cel-kernel strategy modifies the paired imp c-kernel strategy by replacing L=NùíÆùêøsubscriptùëÅùíÆL=N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_L = italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in (20) with the expected value of LùêøLitalic_L given in (18). That is, the modified weights are given by

wùíÆ‚àù2‚Å¢pùíÆ1‚àí(1‚àí2‚Å¢pùíÆ)ùîº‚Å¢[L]/2.proportional-tosubscriptùë§ùíÆ2subscriptùëùùíÆ1superscript12subscriptùëùùíÆùîºdelimited-[]ùêø2\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{S}}\propto\frac{2p_{\mathcal{S}}}{1-(1-2p_{\mathcal{% S}})^{\mathbb{E}[L]/2}}.italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àù divide start_ARG 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - ( 1 - 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_L ] / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (21)

This adjustment ensures that the Shapley value approximations obtained by the paired imp cel-kernel strategy converges to the exact Shapley values when NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approaches 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is illustrated by the black dotted curves in Figure 2 converging to the normalized Shapley kernel weights in (8).

4 Numerical Simulation Studies

A major problem in evaluating explanation frameworks is that real-world data has no true Shapley value explanations. In this section, we consider two setups where we simulate Gaussian data for which we can compute the true/exact Shapley values œïbold-italic-œï{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_œï using all 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coalitions. We then compare how close the approximated Shapley values œïùíüsubscriptbold-italic-œïùíü{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{\mathcal{D}}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are œïbold-italic-œï{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_œï using the different strategies and based on the coalitions in ùíü‚äÇùí´‚Å¢(‚Ñ≥)ùíüùí´‚Ñ≥{\mathcal{D}}\subset{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{M}})caligraphic_D ‚äÇ caligraphic_P ( caligraphic_M ). This paper does not focus on estimating the contribution functions v‚Å¢(S)ùë£ùëÜv(S)italic_v ( italic_S ) but on strategies for selecting the coalitions ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S. Thus, we compute the v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) once using the gaussian approach in the shapr-package \parenciteshapr or analytical results, store them, and load the needed v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values for the sampling strategies.

The gaussian approach in shapr generate conditional samples ùíôùíÆ (k)superscriptsubscriptùíô ùíÆùëò\boldsymbol{x}_{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}^{(k)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from p‚Å¢(ùíôùíÆ |ùíôùíÆ=ùíôùíÆ‚àó)ùëùconditionalsubscriptùíô ùíÆsubscriptùíôùíÆsuperscriptsubscriptùíôùíÆp(\boldsymbol{x}_{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}|% \boldsymbol{x}_{\mathcal{S}}=\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathcal{S}}^{*})italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), for k=1,2,‚Ä¶,Kùëò12‚Ä¶ùêæk=1,2,\dots,Kitalic_k = 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_K and ùíÆ‚ààùí´‚àó‚Å¢(‚Ñ≥)ùíÆsuperscriptùí´‚Ñ≥{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{P}}^{*}({\mathcal{M}})caligraphic_S ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_M ), and use them in (3) to accurately estimate the contribution functions. The parameters ùùÅùùÅ{\boldsymbol{\mu}}bold_italic_Œº and ùö∫ùö∫{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}bold_Œ£ are easily estimated using the sample mean and covariance matrix of the training data, respectively. However, we provide the true parameters to shapr to eliminate the uncertainty in estimating them and to obtain the true Shapley values.

We evaluate the performance of the sampling strategies by computing the averaged mean absolute error (MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE) between the exact (œïbold-italic-œï{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_œï) and approximated (œïùíüsubscriptbold-italic-œïùíü{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{\mathcal{D}}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) Shapley values, averaged over BùêµBitalic_B repetitions (different seeds), NexplainsubscriptùëÅexplainN_{\text{explain}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT explicands, and MùëÄMitalic_M features. A similar criterion has been used in \textciteredelmeier2020, aas2019explaining, aas2021explaining, Olsen2022, olsen2024comparative, olsen2023precision. The MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE is given by

MAE=MAE¬ØB‚Å¢(œï,œïùíü)=1B‚Å¢‚àëb=1BMAEb=1B‚Å¢‚àëb=1B1Nexplain‚Å¢‚àëi=1Nexplain1M‚Å¢‚àëj=1M|œïi,j‚àíœïùíüb,i,j|.MAEsubscript¬ØMAEùêµbold-italic-œïsubscriptbold-italic-œïùíü1ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùëè1ùêµsubscriptMAEùëè1ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùëè1ùêµ1subscriptùëÅexplainsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅexplain1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÄsubscriptitalic-œïùëñùëósubscriptitalic-œïsubscriptùíüùëèùëñùëó\displaystyle\operatorname{MAE}=\overline{\operatorname{MAE}}_{B}({\boldsymbol% {\phi}},{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{\mathcal{D}})=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{b=1}^{B}% \operatorname{MAE}_{b}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{b=1}^{B}\frac{1}{N_{\text{explain}}}% \sum_{i=1}^{N_{\text{explain}}}\frac{1}{M}\sum_{j=1}^{M}|\phi_{i,j}-\phi_{{% \mathcal{D}}_{b},i,j}|.roman_MAE = over¬Ø start_ARG roman_MAE end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_œï , bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_MAE start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_M end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | . (22)

To speed up the computations, we recycle the sampled coalitions for strategies using the same sampling procedure. That is, the paired, paired average, paired kernel, paired c-kernel, and paired cel-kernel strategies all use the same sampling procedure before weighing the coalitions differently. Furthermore, the paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies also share their sampling procedure, while the unique strategy has a separate sampling procedure. To mitigate a separate sampling step for each increasing value of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we sample a sequence/set of coalitions ùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D until all 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coalitions are included and keep track of at which index the sequence contains NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions. We can then efficiently ‚Äúsample‚Äù the set ùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D with NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions by extracting the coalitions up to this index from the sequence. This is done for each of the BùêµBitalic_B repetitions.

Remark: The sampling step is more expensive for the first six strategies in Section 3 due to the repeated sampling with replacements. More precisely, the sampling procedure is time-consuming when NùíÆ‚âà2MsubscriptùëÅùíÆsuperscript2ùëÄN_{\mathcal{S}}\approx 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âà 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and MùëÄMitalic_M is large as the probability of sampling one of the NùíÆ‚àí|ùíü|subscriptùëÅùíÆùíüN_{\mathcal{S}}-|{\mathcal{D}}|italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - | caligraphic_D | remaining unique coalitions is minuscule and takes many iterations. For the paired sampling procedure in the M=20ùëÄ20M=20italic_M = 20-dimensional setting in Section 4.2, we sample on average L=80‚Äâ738‚Äâ405ùêø80738405L=80\,738\,405italic_L = 80 738 405 coalitions before we have 2M=1‚Äâ048‚Äâ576superscript2ùëÄ10485762^{M}=1\,048\,5762 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 048 576 unique coalitions. In Figure 15 in Appendix C, we plot the average LùêøLitalic_L and E‚Å¢[L]ùê∏delimited-[]ùêøE[L]italic_E [ italic_L ] as functions of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for different values of MùëÄMitalic_M. In contrast, the sampling procedure used by the paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies is almost instantaneous due to direct sampling without replacement. For the paired kernel and paired cel-kernel strategies, which do not use the sampling frequencies or sequence length, we can speed up the sampling by listing all possible coalitions and conducting weighted sampling without replacements with pùíÆsubscriptùëùùíÆp_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (8) as sampling probabilities. However, listing all coalitions is impossible if MùëÄMitalic_M is too large. When the coalitions in ùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D are determined, the computation of the approximated Shapley values in (7) is computed in the order of seconds as we load the stored v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values and do not have to compute them. In general, the computation of the contribution functions is often the most computationally demanding part \parenciteolsen2024comparative.

4.1 XGBoost Model

We let M=10ùëÄ10M=10italic_M = 10 and Ntrain=Nexplain=1000subscriptùëÅtrainsubscriptùëÅexplain1000N_{\text{train}}=N_{\text{explain}}=1000italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT train end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1000. We generate the data according to a multivariate Gaussian distribution ùíô‚àºùí©M‚Å¢(ùüé,Œ£)similar-toùíôsubscriptùí©ùëÄ0Œ£\boldsymbol{x}\sim\mathcal{N}_{M}(\boldsymbol{0},\Sigma)bold_italic_x ‚àº caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_0 , roman_Œ£ ), where Œ£Œ£\Sigmaroman_Œ£ is the equi-correlation matrix555We obtain nearly identical results when Œ£i,j=œÅ|i‚àíj|subscriptŒ£ùëñùëósuperscriptùúåùëñùëó\Sigma_{i,j}=\rho^{\left|i-j\right|}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_œÅ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_i - italic_j | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.. We fit a cross-validated xgboost model \parencitechen2015xgboost to this regression problem to act as the predictive model fùëìfitalic_f. To obtain the true/exact Shapley values œïbold-italic-œï{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_œï, we use Monte Carlo integration with K=5000ùêæ5000K=5000italic_K = 5000 Monte Carlo samples for each coalition and explicand. This is done using the gaussian approach in the shapr-package and the true Shapley values are illustrated with sina plots in Appendix D. We repeat the sampling strategies B=500ùêµ500B=500italic_B = 500 times as they are stochastic.

In Figure 3, we plot the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE curves for the different strategies and dependence levels as a function of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also include 95%percent9595\%95 % empirical confidence bands to illustrate the uncertainty in the 500500500500 repeated experiments. Our novel strategies outperform the other established unique and paired sampling strategies for all dependence levels. The state-of-the-art paired strategy outperforms the unique strategy. Still, it is (almost) uniformly outperformed by our paired average, paired c-kernel, and paired cel-kernel strategies by a significant margin. This means that the simple weight-stabilizing technique in the paired average strategy lowers the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE values. However, the paired c-kernel strategy, which uses the corrected Shapley kernel weights instead of the stabilized sampling frequencies, gives additional improvements. Directly using the (uncorrected) Shapley kernel weights, as in the paired kernel strategy, yields poor approximations unless NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Finally, the paired cel-kernel strategy further improves the paired c-kernel strategy by lowering the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores by a small margin.

In general, our novel strategies improve the most upon the established paired strategy for the larger dependence levels, and the difference in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores between the strategies increases when NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases. The paired c-kernel and paired cel-kernel strategies produce slightly more accurate Shapley value approximations than the paired average strategy. However, the difference is mainly noticeable for larger values of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We discuss this difference more at the end of the section.

The paired imp c-kernel strategy performs very well for low values of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, after including all coalitions up to size 3 (and their complements), the precision of the approximated Shapley values deteriorates, and the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores drastically increase. We do not have an explicit explanation for the location of the dip, and we include it as a part of further research in Section 6. However, the increase in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE values when NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT tends to 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is as expected and explained in Section 3.7. This behavior is corrected by the paired imp cel-kernel strategy.

The paired imp cel-kernel strategy is the best strategy in the simulation study and is on par with or outperforms all other strategies. It is only marginally outperformed by the paired average and paired c-kernel strategies for low values of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that the paired imp cel-kernel strategy tends to obtain increased precision when it includes all coalitions of the same size, i.e., the dips in the curves at the dashed vertical lines in Figure 3. The dips are very evident for higher dependence levels. The paired kernel strategy outperforms the paired strategy for larger values of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Still, it is never at the same precision level as the paired average, paired c-kernel, paired cel-kernel, and paired imp cel-kernel strategies.

The MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE values should be interpreted together with fùëìfitalic_f to better understand the scale of the errors. 4.2 Linear Regression Model

In the second simulation study, we investigate a larger dimensional setup. However, we are limited by the computational complexity of the true Shapley values growing exponentially with the number of features. In Figure 9, we plot the relative difference in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores to illustrate that there are differences in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores for the paired average, paired c-kernel, and paired cel-kernel strategies, except for œÅ=0ùúå0\rho=0italic_œÅ = 0. From the solid confidence bands, which showcase the uncertainty around MAE¬Ø500subscript¬ØMAE500\overline{\operatorname{MAE}}_{500}over¬Ø start_ARG roman_MAE end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 500 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we see that the paired average strategy is outperformed by the paired c-kernel strategy on average. This is especially evident for large values of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. While the paired c-kernel strategy is outperformed by the paired cel-kernel strategy on average. Based on the overlapping dashed confidence bands, which showcase the uncertainty between the BùêµBitalic_B repetitions, we see that the order of the strategies can change for some repetitions. However, we want to stress that the difference in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE values for the simple paired c-kernel and more complex paired cel-kernel strategies is minuscule and would most likely not affect a practitioner, i.e., the simple paired c-kernel strategy is sufficient in practice.

We obtain similar results to those in Figure 7 for other linear simulation experiments not included in this paper with M‚àà{10,12,14,17,20}ùëÄ1012141720M\in\{10,12,14,17,20\}italic_M ‚àà { 10 , 12 , 14 , 17 , 20 } and different coefficient values and correlation matrices. The lack of dips at the vertical dashed lines in Figure 7, which we observed in Figure 3, are not an artifact of the equi-correlation matrix as they do not appear when we replace the block equi-correlation matrix with the full equi-correlation matrix. However, the gap between the paired strategy and the paired average, paired c-kernel, and paired cel-kernel strategies further increases and the dip in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE value for the paired imp cel-kernel strategy, which is stable at around NùíÆ=700‚Äâ000subscriptùëÅùíÆ700000N_{\mathcal{S}}=700\,000italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 700 000 in Figure 7, moves gradually from 600‚Äâ000600000600\,000600 000 to 400‚Äâ000400000400\,000400 000 when increasing œÅùúå\rhoitalic_œÅ from 0.20.20.20.2 to 0.90.90.90.9.

We consider the Red Wine data set from the UCI Machine Learning Repository to evaluate the sampling strategies on real non-Gaussian data. 6 Conclusion and Further Work

A major drawback of the Shapley value explanation framework is its computational complexity, which grows exponentially with the number of features. The KernelSHAP approximation framework addresses this by approximating Shapley values as the solution to a weighted least squares problem using a sampled subset ùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D of the 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coalitions \parencitelundberg2017unified. We introduce several novel strategies for selecting ùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D and weighing its NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique elements. Our paired average strategy extends the state-of-the-art paired strategy \parencitecovert2021improving within the KernelSHAP framework by pairing not only the sampling frequencies of paired coalitions but also within the different coalition sizes. By averaging the sampling frequencies within each coalition size, we ensure faster and more stable convergence to the Shapley kernel weights. The novel paired c-kernel strategy directly utilizes the Shapley kernel weights but corrects them based on the sampled subset. While the paired cel-kernel strategy takes the expectation over the subset to remove the variance and produce deterministic weights. The paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies determine the subset of coalitions in a semi-deterministic way by including the most important coalitions first.

Through simulation studies and real-world data examples, we demonstrate that our strategies lead to uniformly more accurate Shapley value explanations using fewer coalitions than competing strategies. More specifically, the paired strategy is consistently outperformed by the paired average strategy, which in turn is outperformed by the paired c-kernel strategy. The more complex paired cel-kernel strategy outperforms the paired c-kernel strategy. However, the difference is negligible and unlikely to affect practical applications. The paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies, especially the latter, produce the most accurate Shapley value approximations of all strategies within certain ranges of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values, but it is often significantly worse outside these regions. Identifying these regions in advance is challenging. Based on our simulation studies and experiments, we recommend the paired c-kernel strategy for its simplicity and consistently high accuracy.

We identify four potential areas for further research. First, we can develop a deeper understanding of when and why the paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies perform well. This analysis should explore whether certain data properties or model characteristics influence their effectiveness. Second, we may extend and enhance our strategies by guiding the sampling of coalitions toward more informative coalitions using pilot estimates. We outline preliminary work on this idea in Appendix E. Third, we can theoretically prove the variance reduction properties of, e.g., the paired average and paired c-kernel strategies, similar to the proof provided by \textcite[Theorem 1.]covert2021improving for the paired strategy. Additionally, investigate whether these weighting schemes are optimal or if better alternatives can be discovered. In a smaller-dimensional setup, one can consider brute force to see if we can find another set of better weights. We can then use the findings to build intuition and extend it to higher dimensions and theoretical results. Fourth, we can compare our strategies with those proposed for other Shapley value approximation frameworks beyond KernelSHAP. For instance, strategies for the random order value formulation have been proposed by \textcitemitchell2022sampling, van2018new, illes2019estimation, castro2017improving. Notably, \textcitemitchell2022sampling find that a paired sampling strategy achieves near-best convergence compared to more complex alternatives. Additionally, comparisons could include the projected gradient descent strategy by \textcitesimon2020projected or the amortized explanation model by \textcitefastshap, which uses a neural network to directly output approximated Shapley values for classification problems.

The main computational burden of approximating Shapley values lies in estimating the contribution function values v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) rather than sampling and determining the weights of the coalitions ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S. Therefore, our proposed strategies, which reduce the number of unique coalitions NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT while maintaining the accuracy of the approximated Shapley values, are very computationally beneficial. For example, we approximately halve the computation cost and time when we halve the number of coalitions. In Figure 6, we illustrate the reduction in NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when using the paired c-kernel strategy to achieve the same accuracy as the unique and paired strategies. The paired c-kernel strategy reduces the required number of coalitions by 50%percent5050\%50 % to 95%percent9595\%95 % compared to the unique strategy and by 25%percent2525\%25 % to 50%percent5050\%50 % compared to the paired strategy, depending on NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the dependence level between the features. This substantial decrease significantly lowers the computational cost and time for Shapley value explanations, making them more feasible in practical applications.

In Appendix A, we describe the implementation details. Appendix A Implementation Details

We use version 0.2.3.9200 of the shapr-package in R available on GitHub \parenciteshapr as a code foundation. In this version, the only sampling strategy in the package is the unique strategy from Section 3.1. We have implemented the other strategies introduced in Sections 3.2, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 3.6 and 3.7 and Appendix E. To generate the true contribution functions and Shapley values in Section 4.1, we have used the gaussian approach in shapr with K=5000ùêæ5000K=5000italic_K = 5000 Monte Carlo Samples from the true Gaussian data distribution. While we used explicit formulas for the contribution function in Section 4.2. In Section 5, we used the random forest separate regression approach introduced in \textciteolsen2024comparative to compute the contribution functions. For the pilot estimates in Appendix E, we use the linear model separate regression approach introduced in \textciteolsen2024comparative due to its rapid computations. We run the code on a shared computer server running Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.5. The server has two Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6226R CPU@2.90GHz (16 cores, 32 threads each) and 768GB DDR4 RAM. Since the memory usage is limited, all simulations can be run on a desktop computer, but at cost of increased elapsed time. Computing the exact Shapley values are the most computational demanding.

Appendix B From Paired Average to Paired Kernel

That is, we sample the chosen NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions an additional LùêøLitalic_L times to make the corresponding sampling frequencies more accurate estimates of the Shapley kernel weights. We observe a gradual increase in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE when we increase LùêøLitalic_L. This demonstrates that the stabilized sampling frequencies are better weights than the Shapley kernel weights when approximating Shapley values using the KernelSHAP framework.

Appendix D Sina Plots of the Shapley Values

In Sections 4 and 5, we discussed that the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores have to be interpreted in connection to the magnitude of the Shapley values/function fùëìfitalic_f, and we used averages to pinpoint what we considered a low MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE. In this section, we provide sina plots, also called beeswarm plots, to illustrate the different scales of the Shapley values; hence, using averages gives a rough estimate. In Figures 18, 17 and 19, we include sina plots of the Shapley values œïbold-italic-œï{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_œï in the simulation studies and examples in Sections 4.1, 4.2 and 5. For the simulation studies, we see that the magnitude of the Shapley values for X1subscriptùëã1X_{1}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, X7subscriptùëã7X_{7}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and X15subscriptùëã15X_{15}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are larger than the other features, which makes sense due to their larger coefficients compared to the other features in the data generating processes. We also see that the Shapley values are more evenly distributed among the features for larger feature dependencies, a well-known property of the conditional Shapley value framework \parencitechen2020true.

Appendix E Additional Sampling Strategies

We have investigated more sampling strategies than those discussed in Section 3, but we excluded them due to their very similar or generally poor performance. However, for the sake of completeness, we provide an overview of the strategies in Section E.1 and we elaborate on the two piloted strategies in Sections E.2 and E.3. In Section E.4, we compare and evaluate the strategies on the same experiments as in Sections 4 and 5.

E.1 Sampling Strategies: Overview

In this section, we provide an overview of the additional sampling strategies that we explored and we split them into two lists. In the first list, we introduce the additional strategies whose results we include in Section E.4, while the second list contains the strategies that are excluded due to their poor performance. The strategies ending with kernel and empirical use the Shapley kernel weights (Section 3.4) and the empirical mean sampling frequencies (explained below), respectively.

  1. Paired empirical:

    The paired empirical strategy extends the paired average strategy by repeating the sampling step to obtain a more stable estimate of the weights for each coalition size, i.e., reduce their variance. That is, we repeat the sampling procedure 250250250250 times and use the empirical means as the new weights. This extra sampling step is independent of the model and explicands and only depends on the number of features. Thus, these weights can be precomputed, stored, and used when applicable. This strategy performs very similar to the paired c-kernel and paired cel-kernel strategies.

  2. Paired largest empirical:

    The paired largest empirical strategy uses the empirical mean weights introduced by the paired empirical strategy but rather includes paired coalitions based on their weights in decreasing order, as the paired imp c-kernel strategy in Section 3.7. This strategy performs very similar to the paired imp cel-kernel strategy.

  3. Paired largest kernel:

    This strategy is equivalent to the paired largest empirical strategy except for using the Shapley kernel weights instead of the empirical mean sampling frequencies. That is, we add the coalitions with the largest Shapley kernel weights first in increasing order and paired manner. Then we sample coalitions with uniform probability for the coalition size where not all coalitions are included.

  4. Paired largest order kernel:

    Identical to the paired largest kernel strategy except that we rather add the coalitions in order and paired manner for coalition sizes where not all coalitions are included. To elaborate, in the example given in Section 3.7, the latter three coalitions would be {1,2,3}123\{1,2,3\}{ 1 , 2 , 3 }, the pair {4,5,6,7,8,9,10}45678910\{4,5,6,7,8,9,10\}{ 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 , 8 , 9 , 10 }, and {1,2,4}124\{1,2,4\}{ 1 , 2 , 4 }. Then we use the Shapley kernel weights.

  5. Paired largest order empirical:

    Identical to the paired largest order kernel strategy except that we use the empirical mean sampling frequencies as the weights.

  6. Pilot average:

    Identical to the paired average strategy except that we sample the coalitions using the piloted importance weights for each coalition introduced in Section E.2 instead of using the Shapley kernel weights. This means that the distribution of the stabilized sampling frequencies will not tend to the Shapley kernel weights, and the strategy will give inaccurate approximations when NùíÆ‚Üí2M‚ÜísubscriptùëÅùíÆsuperscript2ùëÄN_{\mathcal{S}}\to 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  7. Pilot empirical:

    Identical to the pilot average strategy except that we replace the sampling frequencies at the end with the empirical mean sampling frequencies. Conceptually, this ensures that we sample important coalitions but weigh them such that we obtain the exact Shapley values when NùíÆ‚Üí2M‚ÜísubscriptùëÅùíÆsuperscript2ùëÄN_{\mathcal{S}}\to 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  8. Pilot largest kernel:

    We add the coalitions based on the order of importance based on the pilot estimates and then use the Shapley kernel weights. That is, no sampling is conducted.

  9. Pilot largest empirical:

    Identical to the pilot largest kernel strategy except that we use the empirical mean sampling frequencies as the weights.

  10. MAD largest kernel:

    Identical to the paired largest kernel strategy except that instead of sampling the remaining coalitions, we use the procedure outlined in Section E.3 to determine the most important coalitions and include them based on the order of importance. Then we use the Shapley kernel weights.

  11. MAD largest empirical:

    Identical to the MAD largest kernel strategy except that we use the empirical mean sampling frequencies as the weights.

We now present the strategies not included in Section E.4 as they performed poorly.

  1. Order increasing kernel:

    Add coalitions based on the ordering introduced in the Section 3. That is, we add all coalitions of size one, then size two, and so on.

  2. Order decreasing kernel:

    Add coalitions based on the reverse ordering introduced in the Section 3. That is, we add all coalitions of size M‚àí1ùëÄ1M-1italic_M - 1, then size M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and so on.

  3. Paired smallest kernel:

    Add coalitions with the smallest Shapley kernel weights first in decreasing order and paired manner. I.e., the reverse order of the paired largest kernel strategy.

  4. Largest coalition kernel:

    Add the coalitions with the largest Shapley kernel weights first but in increasing coalition size (i.e., no paired sampling). E.g., for M=4ùëÄ4M=4italic_M = 4, we would add the coalitions in the following order: {1}1\left\{1\right\}{ 1 }, {2}2\left\{2\right\}{ 2 }, {3}3\left\{3\right\}{ 3 }, {4}4\left\{4\right\}{ 4 }, {1,2,3}123\left\{1,2,3\right\}{ 1 , 2 , 3 }, {1,2,4}124\left\{1,2,4\right\}{ 1 , 2 , 4 }, {1,3,4}134\left\{1,3,4\right\}{ 1 , 3 , 4 }, {2,3,4}234\left\{2,3,4\right\}{ 2 , 3 , 4 }, {1,2}12\left\{1,2\right\}{ 1 , 2 }, {1,3}13\left\{1,3\right\}{ 1 , 3 }, {1,4}14\left\{1,4\right\}{ 1 , 4 }, {2,3}23\left\{2,3\right\}{ 2 , 3 }, {2,4}24\left\{2,4\right\}{ 2 , 4 }, and {3,4}34\left\{3,4\right\}{ 3 , 4 }.

  5. Smallest coalition kernel:

    Add the coalitions with the smallest Shapley kernel weights first but in decreasing coalition size (i.e., no paired sampling). I.e., the reverse order of the largest coalition kernel strategy.

E.2 Sampling Strategies: Pilot

The pilot strategies are motivated by the fact that some coalitions often are more critical than others in the Shapley value computations. Thus, we should include these coalitions when approximating the Shapley values. The strategies in Section 3 sample the coalitions only based on the coalition size |ùíÆ|ùíÆ|{\mathcal{S}}|| caligraphic_S | and do not take v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) into consideration (as they are not available). We propose to compute (rough) pilot estimates v~‚Å¢(S)~ùë£ùëÜ\tilde{v}(S)over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG ( italic_S ) of v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) and include these in the sampling procedure. We use a linear regression model to estimate v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ), i.e., the linear model separate regression approach in \textciteolsen2024comparative. This approach was chosen for its low computational cost.

It is conceptually possible that all coalitions are important for some combinations of features and explicands. However, this is not optimal as we want to limit the number of coalitions ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S to compute v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) for. Thus, we average across the features and explicands to determine the NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT most important coalitions on average and use those for all features and explicands. We can then look at the |ùëªj,k[i]|subscriptsuperscriptùëªdelimited-[]ùëñùëóùëò|\boldsymbol{T}^{[i]}_{j,k}|| bold_italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | quantities and average them over the features jùëójitalic_j and explicands iùëñiitalic_i to see which coalitions kùëòkitalic_k that have the largest absolute effect on the Shapley values.

To better understand the pilot idea, consider a small 5555-dimensional toy-example where we have computed the exact v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) quantities for a linear model with coefficients ùú∑=[2,10,0.25,‚àí3,‚àí1,1.5]ùú∑2100.25311.5{\boldsymbol{\beta}}=[2,10,0.25,-3,-1,1.5]bold_italic_Œ≤ = [ 2 , 10 , 0.25 , - 3 , - 1 , 1.5 ] and the data is generated according to a multivariate Gaussian distribution with mean zero and an equi-correlation matrix with œÅ=0.5ùúå0.5\rho=0.5italic_œÅ = 0.5. In Figure 20, we illustrate the corresponding |ùëªj,k[i]|subscriptsuperscriptùëªdelimited-[]ùëñùëóùëò|\boldsymbol{T}^{[i]}_{j,k}|| bold_italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | quantities when averaged only over the explicands and when averaged over both the explicands and features. When only averaged over the explicands, we see that the most important coalition pair for the jùëójitalic_jth feature is when jùëójitalic_j is the only feature in ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S. When we also average over the features, we obtain slightly different weights than when giving all coalitions of the same size the same importance. Ideally, these differences should reflect the importance of the coalition.

We can then add the coalitions in the order of largest importance and use the Shapley kernel weights or the empirical means as the weights. We name these strategies for pilot largest kernel and pilot largest empirical, respectively. Another strategy is to sample the coalitions using these modified weights. However, the approximations will then not converge to the true Shapley values when NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases as we do not sample from the Shapley kernel distribution. We then use over stabilizing technique as in paired average and call the corresponding strategy for pilot average. In the pilot empirical strategy, we replace the final weights with the empirical mean weights.

In further work, we would like to investigate methods for obtaining better and faster pilot estimates (in settings where a linear model is too expensive). Especially in higher dimensions, as we would then most likely have to sample a subset of features, compute pilot estimates of them, and then sample a new subset from the sampled coalitions.

E.3 Sampling Strategies: MAD

Here we modify the paired largest empirical strategy to not add the coalitions randomly, but by using pilot estimates to determine the most important coalitions and then add them. The following setup differs from Section E.2 in that we do not need pilot estimates for the relevant coalition size, i.e., where paired largest empirical sampled coalitions. This means that the number of pilot estimates is reduced from 2Msuperscript2ùëÄ2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to (M|S|)binomialùëÄùëÜ\binom{M}{|S|}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_M end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S | end_ARG ) when |ùíÆ|=|ùíÆ |ùíÆ ùíÆ|{\mathcal{S}}|=|{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}|| caligraphic_S | = | overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG | and 2‚Å¢(M|S|)2binomialùëÄùëÜ2\binom{M}{|S|}2 ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_M end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S | end_ARG ) when |ùíÆ|‚â†|ùíÆ |ùíÆ ùíÆ|{\mathcal{S}}|\neq|{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}|| caligraphic_S | ‚â† | overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG |.

For an important subset of features, we should have that v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) is close to f‚Å¢(ùíô)ùëìùíôf(\boldsymbol{x})italic_f ( bold_italic_x ), as this tells us that the features in ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S can model fùëìfitalic_f accurately. We therefore rank the coalitions based on the mean absolute difference MAD‚Å°(ùíÆ)=1Nexplain‚Å¢‚àëi=1Nexplain|v‚Å¢(ùíÆ;ùíôi)‚àíf‚Å¢(ùíôi)|MADùíÆ1subscriptùëÅexplainsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅexplainùë£ùíÆsubscriptùíôùëñùëìsubscriptùíôùëñ\operatorname{MAD}({\mathcal{S}})=\frac{1}{N_{\text{explain}}}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{% \text{explain}}}|v({\mathcal{S}};\boldsymbol{x}_{i})-f(\boldsymbol{x}_{i})|roman_MAD ( caligraphic_S ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_v ( caligraphic_S ; bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) |. Coalitions containing less than half the features contain important features if the MADMAD\operatorname{MAD}roman_MAD is low. While the MADMAD\operatorname{MAD}roman_MAD is high for coalitions containing more than half the features but where important features are missing.
