For coalitions where |ùíÆ|‚â†|ùíÆ |ùíÆ ùíÆ|{\mathcal{S}}|\neq|{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}|| caligraphic_S | ‚â† | overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG |, we order the coalitions in an increasing paired manner based on the difference between MAD‚Å°(ùíÆ)MADùíÆ\operatorname{MAD}({\mathcal{S}})roman_MAD ( caligraphic_S ) and MAD‚Å°(ùíÆ )MAD ùíÆ\operatorname{MAD}({\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}})roman_MAD ( overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG ). A potential modification to the MAD largest strategy to make it stochastic is to use the scaled inverse mean absolute distance MAD‚àí1‚Å°(ùíÆ)superscriptMAD1ùíÆ\operatorname{MAD}^{-1}({\mathcal{S}})roman_MAD start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_S ) as weights.

E.4 Sampling Strategies: Results

The results of the additional strategies for the XGBoost and linear experiments are provided in Figures 21 and 22, respectively. For the linear experiment, we have reduced MùëÄMitalic_M from twenty to seventeen and use the first seventeen coefficients and rows/columns in the block equi-correlation matrix. While the results for the Red Wine data set experiment is provided in Figure 23. Additionally, we use fewer repetitions BùêµBitalic_B and a coarser set of NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values. To more easily compare Figures 21 and 22 with Figures 3, 7 and 10 we include the paired kernel strategy in all figures, while the paired empirical and paired largest empirical strategies can be though off as proxies for the paired cel-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies as their performance is more or less identical. Thus, we only include the former two. For all experiments, we see that the additional strategies perform on par or worse than the strategies included in Section 4. The kernel based strategies perform worse than the empirical strategies. The performance of the strategies in the Red Wine data set is closer to those observed in the linear than in the XGBoost experiments.

By comparing the paired largest empirical and paired largest order empirical strategies, we see that randomly adding the coalitions is better than adding them based on the chronological coalition order introduced in Section 4. This is intuitive, as the random order over BùêµBitalic_B repetitions will better explore the importance of the coalitions than the single deterministic order. However, they match up at the dashed vertical lines when all coalitions of a given size are included.

The motivation behind the MAD largest empirical and pilot largest empirical is to determine the best order to add the coalitions based on pilot estimates. However, neither strategy outperforms the random inclusion done in the paired largest empirical strategy. We observe (more or less) identical curves when we use the true v‚Å¢(ùíÆ)ùë£ùíÆv({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) quantities as the pilot estimates v~‚Å¢(ùíÆ)~ùë£ùíÆ\tilde{v}({\mathcal{S}})over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG ( caligraphic_S ) (figures not included). This implies that imprecise pilot estimates are not to blame but rather that the setups in Sections E.2 and E.3 are sub-optimal. Note that the strategies match up at the dashed vertical lines as they include all (paired) coalitions of one size before including coalitions of another size (see the weights in Figure 20). In a smaller-dimensional setup, brute force can be considered to try to discover the optimal coalitions to include, and then use this information to build intuition and create a better importance criterion than those proposed in Sections E.2 and E.3.

The MSEMSE\operatorname{MSE}roman_MSE curves related to the pilot average strategy are ‚ÄúU‚Äù-shaped. The rising errors when NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases are caused by sampling from a distribution different than the Shapley kernel distribution, meaning that our approximated Shapley values œïùíüsubscriptbold-italic-œïùíü{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{\mathcal{D}}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will not converge to œïbold-italic-œï{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_œï when NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases.

All the kernel-based strategies (paired kernel, paired largest kernel, paired largest order kernel, pilot largest kernel, and MAD largest kernel) perform similarly to each other, and worse than the empirical-based counter strategies. Furthermore, the paired kernel is often the worst, which means that randomly selecting the coalitions is worse than adding the coalitions based on, e.g., the decreasing order of the magnitude of the Shapley kernel weights.

The erratic behavior of the MAD largest kernel and MAD largest empirical strategies in Figure 21 for |ùíÆ|=5ùíÆ5|{\mathcal{S}}|=5| caligraphic_S | = 5 is due to the procedure described in Section E.3 not doing paired sampling when |ùíÆ|=ùíÆ ||{\mathcal{S}}|={\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}|| caligraphic_S | = overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG |. This only happens when MùëÄMitalic_M is even, hence we do not see the same behavior in Figures 21 and 23. This illustrates the importance of paired sampling and how it stabilizes and improves the approximations. A potential modification/fix would be to also enforce pairing in the |ùíÆ|=|ùíÆ |ùíÆ ùíÆ|{\mathcal{S}}|=|{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}|| caligraphic_S | = | overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG | setting.

Appendix F Comparing Paired CEL-Kernel and Paired CEPS-Kernel

In this section, we illustrate that using (19) with ùîº‚Å¢[L]ùîºdelimited-[]ùêø\mathbb{E}[L]blackboard_E [ italic_L ] or employing wùíÆ‚àùùîº‚Å¢[p~ùíÆ]proportional-tosubscriptùë§ùíÆùîºdelimited-[]subscript~ùëùùíÆw_{\mathcal{S}}\propto\mathbb{E}[\tilde{p}_{\mathcal{S}}]italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àù blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] yields equally precise Shapley value approximations in our simulation studies. To estimate ùîº‚Å¢[p~ùíÆ]ùîºdelimited-[]subscript~ùëùùíÆ\mathbb{E}[\tilde{p}_{\mathcal{S}}]blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], we simulate 1000100010001000 LùêøLitalic_L values, compute p~ùíÆsubscript~ùëùùíÆ\tilde{p}_{\mathcal{S}}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each, and then take the mean. We refer to this method as the paired ceps-kernel strategy. In Figures 24 and 25, we plot the relative difference between the paired cel-kernel and paired ceps-kernel strategies, with the former as the reference, for the simulation study in Sections 4.1 and 4.2, respectively. We clearly see that their performance is more or less equivalent. The figures for the real-world experiment in Section 5 (not included) tell the exact same story, indicating that there is no meaningful difference between the two strategies in our simulation studies and experiments.

Appendix G The SHAP Python Library

In this section, we demonstrate that our novel techniques can significantly enhance the strategy used in the popular SHAP Python library \parenciteshap_python, which we name PySHAP. We briefly explain PySHAP below, while more detailed descriptions can be found in \textcite[Section 2.2.5]herren2022statistical and \textcite[Appendix B]fumagalli2024kernelshap. Upon examining the implementation of PySHAP in version 0.46.0 of SHAP (the latest version at the current date), we observed that it explicitly does not pair coalitions for the coalition size where |ùíÆ|=|ùíÆ |ùíÆ ùíÆ|{\mathcal{S}}|=|{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}|| caligraphic_S | = | overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG |, a condition only relevant if MùëÄMitalic_M is even. It remains unclear to us whether this is an intentional design choice or an oversight. Based on this finding, and drawing on the techniques discussed in Sections 3.3 and 3.5, we propose modifications to PySHAP at the end of this section and conduct benchmarking to assess their efficacy.

We now describe the sampling and weighting procedure in PySHAP before providing an illustrative example for clarity. The PySHAP strategy divides the sampling procedure into a deterministic and sampling-based part based on the number of unique coalitions NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It deterministically includes all coalitions of size |ùíÆ|ùíÆ|{\mathcal{S}}|| caligraphic_S | and M‚àí|ùíÆ|ùëÄùíÆM-|{\mathcal{S}}|italic_M - | caligraphic_S | if the number of remaining coalitions to sample NùíÆ‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT exceeds the expected number of coalitions needed to sample all coalitions of these sizes, i.e., 2‚Å¢(M|ùíÆ|)2binomialùëÄùíÆ2\binom{M}{|{\mathcal{S}}|}2 ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_M end_ARG start_ARG | caligraphic_S | end_ARG ). The strategy begins with coalition size one and increments by one until the number of remaining coalitions NùíÆ‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT becomes insufficient. The first modification we propose to PySHAP is to always pair the coalitions, and we name this strategy PySHAP*. Note that PySHAP and PySHAP* are equivalent when MùëÄMitalic_M is odd. Furthermore, we introduce the PySHAP*‚Äâaverage and PySHAP*‚Äâc-kernel strategies, which apply the averaging and correction techniques described in Sections 3.3 and 3.5, respectively. Additionally, we present the PySHAP*‚Äâcel-kernel strategy, which uses the sampling order determined by PySHAP* but applies the weights introduced in Section 3.6. In Figure 26, we illustrate the sampled coalitions and normalized weights generated by the five different strategies for an increasing number of unique coalitions NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in an M=10ùëÄ10M=10italic_M = 10-dimensional setting.

The results of the PySHAP-based strategies for the XGBoost (Section 4.1), linear (Section 4.2), and real-world (Section 5) experiments are shown in Figures 27, 28 and 29, respectively. We omit the 95%percent9595\%95 % confidence bands in these plots because the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE curves are now closer together than in earlier analyses presented in Sections 4 and 5, as their inclusion makes the plot more difficult to interpret. For comparison, we also include some strategies discussed in Section 3. Firstly, we observe that our PySHAP* strategy significantly improves upon the PySHAP strategy in the SHAP Python library when MùëÄMitalic_M is even. Both the PySHAP*‚Äâaverage and PySHAP*‚Äâc-kernel strategies further enhance the PySHAP* strategy, with their nearly identical performance ‚Äìevidenced by their overlapping MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE curves. The PySHAP*‚Äâcel-kernel strategy offers additional improvements, except for the linear experiment shown in Figure 28, where the corresponding MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE curves experience positive jumps before decreasing again with increasing NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values. Overall, the PySHAP*‚Äâc-kernel strategy emerges as the best-performing and most stable PySHAP-based strategy.

The abrupt changes in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE curves for the PySHAP-based strategies correspond to the NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values at which two new coalition sizes are deterministically included. For example, in the M=10ùëÄ10M=10italic_M = 10-dimensional setting in Figure 27, a noticeable improvement occurs at NùíÆ=268subscriptùëÅùíÆ268N_{\mathcal{S}}=268italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 268, corresponding to the inclusion of coalitions of size two and eight, as discussed in the example above. The performance of the PySHAP*‚Äâaverage, PySHAP*‚Äâc-kernel, and PySHAP*‚Äâcel-kernel strategies is comparable to that of the paired c-kernel. An advantage of the former strategies is the reduced number of repeated sampled coalitions as the number of deterministically included coalitions increases with NùíÆsubscriptùëÅùíÆN_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This reduction means there are fewer possible coalitions to sample from compared to the paired c-kernel strategy, which considers all possible coalitions. However, it is important to note that the sampling of coalitions is computationally simple and not the primary computational burden when approximating Shapley values, as discussed in Section 6.
